required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Inhaled Fentanyl on Dyspnea and Exercise Tolerance in Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Inhaled Nebulized Fentanyl on Exertional Dyspnea and Exercise Tolerance in Patients With Moderate-to-severe COPD

brief_summary.textblock: Breathing discomfort (dyspnea) and activity limitation are dominant symptoms of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and contribute to poor health-related quality of life in this population. Several small, uncontrolled studies and published case reports have provided evidence that inhaled fentanyl, a powerful pain relieving (opioid) medication, may be used to effectively reduce breathing discomfort in patients with advanced disease. However, the mechanisms of this improvement remain unclear. Therefore, the investigators plan to conduct the first randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover study designed to explore the possible mechanisms of action of inhaled fentanyl on activity-related dyspnea and exercise performance in patients with advanced COPD.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Dyspnea Intensity Measured by the 10-point Borg Scale During Cycle Exercise
primary_outcome.description: The 10-point Borg scale ranges from 0 "nothing at all" to 10 "maximal/extremely strong" and was used to rate the intensity of dyspnea during exercise; therefore, a decrease in this rating signifies an improvement. Dyspnea intensity was assessed at the highest equivalent standardized time achieved in both post-treatment constant work rate cycle exercise tests.

secondary_outcome.description: Constant workrate cycle endurance during tests at 75% of the peak incremental workrate

intervention.description: single dose, 50 mcg of nebulized fentanyl citrate

overall_official.affiliation: Queen's University and Kingston General Hospital
Queen's University and Kingston General Hospital

facility.name: Respiratory Investigation Unit, Kingston General Hospital

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Recruitment took place between February and October 2010. Subjects were recruited from respiratory outpatient clinics and from a database of subjects who had previously taken part in research studies in COPD.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: No enrolled subjects were excluded prior to group assignment. 7 subjects were assigned a treatment order of fentanyl-placebo (2 were withdrawn after period 1) and 9 subjects were assigned a treatment order of placebo-fentanyl (2 were withdrawn after period 1). Therefore, there was complete data from 12 subjects.

group.title: Placebo - Fentanyl (Order)
group.description: nebulized 0.9% saline placebo in period 1, nebulized fentanyl citrate 50mcg in period 2

group.title: Fentanyl - Placebo (Order)
group.description: nebulized fentanyl citrate (50 mcg) in period 1, nebulized 0.9% saline placebo in period 2

group.title: Placebo - Fentanyl (Order)
group.description: nebulized saline placebo in period 1, nebulized fentanyl citrate in period 2.

group.title: Fentanyl - Placebo (Order)
group.description: nebulized fentanyl citrate in period 1, nebulized saline placebo in period 2.

outcome.title: Dyspnea Intensity Measured by the 10-point Borg Scale During Cycle Exercise
outcome.description: The 10-point Borg scale ranges from 0 "nothing at all" to 10 "maximal/extremely strong" and was used to rate the intensity of dyspnea during exercise; therefore, a decrease in this rating signifies an improvement. Dyspnea intensity was assessed at the highest equivalent standardized time achieved in both post-treatment constant work rate cycle exercise tests.
outcome.population: Subjects who completed both treatment arms of the crossover study were included in the primary analysis.

measure.title: Dyspnea Intensity Measured by the 10-point Borg Scale During Cycle Exercise
measure.description: The 10-point Borg scale ranges from 0 "nothing at all" to 10 "maximal/extremely strong" and was used to rate the intensity of dyspnea during exercise; therefore, a decrease in this rating signifies an improvement. Dyspnea intensity was assessed at the highest equivalent standardized time achieved in both post-treatment constant work rate cycle exercise tests.
measure.population: Subjects who completed both treatment arms of the crossover study were included in the primary analysis.

outcome.title: Cycle Exercise Endurance Time
outcome.description: Constant workrate cycle endurance during tests at 75% of the peak incremental workrate
outcome.population: Subjects completing both treatment arms were included in this analysis

measure.title: Cycle Exercise Endurance Time
measure.description: Constant workrate cycle endurance during tests at 75% of the peak incremental workrate
measure.population: Subjects completing both treatment arms were included in this analysis

reported_events.time_frame: During visit, with appropriate follow-up to resolution of adverse event

event.description: Lightheadedness, dizziness and mild nausea was experienced during and immediately after nebulization of the study medication. Symptoms quickly resolved but resulted in discontinuation from the study.
Severe dyspnea was experienced during the nebulization of study medication. This resolved quickly after discontinuing nebulization but resulted in withdrawal from the study.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
